questions.explanation: Nitric oxide is a neurotransmitter in the CNS.Neurotransmitters are the substances that mediate chemical signaling between neurons. They canbe choline esters, biogenic amines, amino acids, and neuropeptides.Two main classes of chemical substances that serve as neurotransmitters:183• small-molecule neurotransmitter (acetylcholine)•⚫ large molecule neurotransmitter (enkephalin)They can act on ionotropic receptors (ligand-gated ion channels) and/or metabotropic receptors onthe postsynaptic membrane to produce a change in membrane potential to bring about theiraction.Criteria for the substance to be neurotransmitter:•⚫ the substance must be demonstrated to be present in the presynaptic terminal.• the cell must be able to synthesize the substance.•should be released on depolarization of the terminal.••there should be specific receptors for it on the postsynaptic membrane.⚫ if the substance is applied exogenously to the postsynaptic membrane at physiologicconcentration, the response of the postsynaptic cell must mimic the in vivo response.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding metabotropic neurotransmitters?

options.A: They act through second messenger systems
options.B: They bind to cationic channels and increase influx of Na
options.C: They bind to anionic channels and increase influx of Cl
options.D: They inhibit the fusion of synaptic vesicle with the synaptic cleft

questions.explanation: Neurotransmitter receptors that act through second messenger systems are called metabotropicreceptors.Neurotransmitters bind to receptors on the post-synaptic membrane to activate ion channels inone of the two ways:•by gating ion channels directly (ionotropic receptors).• by activating a second messenger (metabotropic receptor) for a prolonged postsynaptic neuronalexcitation or inhibition. Most commonly activated is a G-protein coupled membrane receptor.The following four changes can occur usually after binding to a G-protein coupled receptor:•Opening specific ion channels through the post-synaptic cell membrane.184• Activation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (CAMP) or cyclic guanosine monophosphate(cGMP) in the neuronal cell.• Activation of one or more intracellular enzymes.• Activation of gene transcription. Activation of gene transcription is one of the most importanteffects of activation of the second messenger systems because gene transcription can causeformation of new proteins within the neuron, thereby changing its metabolic machinery or itsstructure.

questions.question: Excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) is due to the influx of

options.A: Na+

questions.explanation: Excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) is due to the influx of sodium ions (Na+).At the post-synaptic membrane, neurotransmitters binding to receptors generate responses thatcan be excitatory or inhibitory. If it generates an excitatory response (makes the membrane moreelectrically positive/ depolarized), it is an excitatory postsynaptic potential (EPSP) because itmakes the cell more likely to reach an action potential.EPSP may be due to• The opening of sodium channels or calcium channels to allow large numbers of positive•electrical charges to flow to the interior of the postsynaptic cell.Depressed conduction through chloride or potassium channels or both.• Various changes in the internal metabolism of the postsynaptic neuron to increase the number ofexcitatory membrane receptors or decrease the number of inhibitory membrane receptors.18830mv-15mv-70mvAs seen in the figure, following the discharge of the sensory neuron, there is positivity in themotor neuron signifying a EPSP.

questions.question: Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potential (IPSP) is due to influx of

options.A: Na+

questions.explanation: Inhibitory Postsynaptic Potential (IPSP) is due to the influx of chloride ions (Cl-).If, binding of a neurotransmitter causes the postsynaptic membrane to become more negative(hyperpolarized), it is called an inhibitory postsynaptic potential (IPSP) because hyperpolarizationmoves the membrane potential farther from the threshold and makes the cell less likely to reachan action potential.IPSP may be due to:• Increase in Cl- influx. This action causes diffusion of negatively charged chloride ions fromoutside the postsynaptic neuron to the inside, thereby carrying negative charges inward andincreasing the negativity inside. This leads to hyperpolarization.•• Increase in K+ efflux. This action causes positive ions to diffuse to the exterior, which causesincreased negativity inside the neuron, which leads to hyperpolarization.• Activation of receptor enzymes that increase the number of inhibitory synaptic receptors ordecrease the number of excitatory receptors.

The slow EPSPs are due to a decrease in K+ efflux,and the slow IPSPs are due to an increase in K+ efflux.

questions.explanation: Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh and prolongsthe action of ACh at the muscle end plate.Myasthenia gravis:•• It is caused by the presence of antibodies to the ACh receptor.• Is characterized by skeletal muscle weakness and fatigability resulting from a reduced number ofACh receptors on the muscle end plate.•The size of the EPP (end plate potential) is reduced.• Treatment with AChE inhibitors (e.g., neostigmine) prevents the degradation of ACh andprolongs the action of ACh at the muscle end plate, partially compensating for the reducednumber of receptors.

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman had an autonomic neuropathy that disrupted the sympathetic nervesupply to the pupillary dilator muscle of her right eye. While having her eyes examined, theophthalmologist placed a sympathomimetic drug in both her eyes. The right eye becamemuch more dilated than the left eye. This suggests that:

options.A: The sympathetic nerve to the right eye had regenerated
options.B: The parasympathetic nerve supply to the right eye remained intact and compensated for theloss of the sympathetic nerve
options.D: The left eye also had nerve damage and so was not responding as expected

questions.explanation: 193Denervation supersensitivity develops in the muscle after the nerve supplying it is cut. Since thenerve to her right dilator pupillae is damaged, the right eye becomes excessively sensitive to thesympathomimetic drug. So, the right eye becomes much more dilated than the left.Denervation Supersensitivity:• When the motor nerve to skeletal muscle is degenerated, the muscle gradually becomes•extremely sensitive to acetylcholine. This is called denervation hypersensitivity or supersensitivity.Normally nicotinic receptors are located only in the vicinity of the motor endplate where theaxon of the motor nerve terminates. When the motor nerve is severed, there is a marked•proliferation of nicotinic receptors over a wide region of the neuromuscular junction.⚫ Denervation supersensitivity also occurs at autonomic junctions. Smooth muscle, unlike skeletalmuscle, does not atrophy when denervated, but it becomes hyperresponsive to the chemicalmediator that normally activates it.• This hyperresponsiveness can be demonstrated by using pharmacologic tools rather than actualnerve section. Prolonged use of a drug such as reserpine can be used to deplete transmitter storesand prevent the target organ from being exposed to norepinephrine for an extended period. Oncethe drug usage is stopped, smooth muscle and cardiac muscle will be supersensitive to subsequentrelease of the neurotransmitter.Option a) If the symapthetic nerve would have regenerated, both right and left eye would havebeen equally sensitive to the drug and so, would have dilated equally.Option b) Parasympathetic nerves supply the spinchter pupillae muscle. So, if stimulated theywould constrict the eye not dilate it. Also, the drug added was a sympathomimetic agent. So,parasympathetic nerves are not stimulated in the first placeOption d) If the left eye was damaged, it would also have denervation supersensitivity. Again, botheyes would dilate equally, but more than that of normal.

questions.question: 179How is an electrical synapse different from a chemical synapse?

options.A: No cytoplasmic continuity between presynaptic and postsynaptic membrane
options.C: Connexons are involved in electrical synapse
options.D: Electrical synapse has more latent period than chemical synapse

questions.explanation: In electrical synapses, the cytoplasm of adjacent cells is directly connected by gap junctions(connexons) that allow free movement of ions from the interior of one cell to the interior of thenext cell.The transmission in electrical synapses is bidirectional and there is no synaptic delay. Unlikechemical synapses, electrical synapse has cytoplasmic continuity.196Note:Most of the synapses used for signal transmission in the central nervous system are chemicalsynapses.197
